tossups.question: Changes that produce “descent” in this property often preserve the irreducible representation symbolized E and lower the number of columns in a character table. Knowledge of the gerade ("guh-RAH-duh") or ungerade (“OON-guh-RAH-duh”) form of this property is sufficient to identify forbidden transitions for an orbital. Spectroscopic selection rules are predicted from this property. All optically active compounds lack a form of this property denoted by the S-sub-n (*) point group, whose elements are three-dimensional isometries. Chiral molecules must lack forms of this property because they have neither inversion centers nor mirror planes. Molecules that can revolve and return to their original position have the rotational form of, for 10 points, what property?
tossups.answer: symmetry [or symmetric; accept descent in symmetry, center of symmetry, or centrosymmetric; accept inversion symmetry, mirror symmetry, symmetry plane, or rotational symmetry]

tossups.question: This poem compares one character falling to a “watch-tower of a town which an earthquake shatters down” before asking, “Pleasure past and anguish past, is it death or is it life?” A character in this poem is told a cautionary tale about a girl who “dwindled and grew grey, then fell with the first snow” and “pined and pined away” named Jeanie. Upon seeing this poem’s title characters “hobbling down the glen,” one character warns how nobody knows “upon what (*) soil they fed their hungry thirsty roots.” The moral that “there is no friend like a sister” appears at the end of this poem, which begins by describing cries to “come buy, come buy.” Despite Laura’s warnings, Lizzie eats the fruits of the title vendors in, for 10 points, what Christina Rossetti poem?
tossups.answer: “Goblin Market”

tossups.question: This technique exploded in popularity in the US in the 1970s following its so-called “discovery” by Paul Dudley White and classification as a deductible tax expense. Practitioners of this technique usually work across twelve basic meridians with objects deemed Class II medical devices by the FDA. The placement of tattoos on Otzi the Iceman may mean that this technique was known in the Copper Age. The devices used for this technique are sometimes also used for moxibustion and can cause a type of (*) numbness known as de-qi (“duh-chee”). Practitioners of this technique seek to restore the body’s chi, thus balancing yin and yang. For 10 points, name this form of traditional Chinese medicine where small needles are inserted into the skin.
tossups.answer: acupuncture [or zhēnjiǔ; prompt on traditional Chinese medicine or Oriental Medicine or alternative medicine or needling or complementary medicine or integrative medicine or zhōngyī]

tossups.question: A language from Jersey uses these two English letters to represent a cross-linguistically rare sound that corresponds to the letter “r” in French. The sounds represented in English by these two letters are fronted in Cockney. In American English, the sounds represented by these letters are pronounced interdentally, but in other dialects they are the voiced and unvoiced dental fricatives. A letter that looks like a “p” with its stem extended upwards was an Old English equivalent of the combination of these two letters and was known as (*) “thorn.” The most common type of lisp involves turning “s” sounds into a sound represented by these two letters. For 10 points, name these two letters that begin English’s most common word.
tossups.answer: th [or t AND h; accept answers that sound like the sound “th” makes in English (either like the beginning of “think” or the beginning of “that”)]

tossups.question: This musical work is often performed alongside a tango suite whose English title suggests it is a version from Buenos Aires; that suite is by Astor Piazzolla. The largo movement of a piece in this collection is also marked pianissimo sempre; in that movement, a viola plays a two-note “always forte” motif. Dancing (*) drunks are represented by the second movement of the third of these pieces. All but the bass play rapid sixteenth-notes to evoke a thunderstorm in movement two of the second piece in this collection. The three movements of each piece in this collection mirror the three sections of an accompanying sonnet. For 10 points, The Contest Between Harmony and Invention opens with what set of four violin concertos by Antonio Vivaldi?
tossups.answer: The Four Seasons [or Le quattro stagioni]

tossups.question: A religious movement in this country has been criticized for its use of an argumentative proselytization method called "break-and-subdue." That movement venerates a calligraphic mandala inscribed by its founder on a log of camphorwood. A pangram about crossing the "deep mountains of karma" called the Iroha is ascribed to a monk from this country, who notably underwent self- (*) mummification. A saying that one should be born in its indigenous religion, marry Christian, and die Buddhist originates from this country, which was the origin of a chant glorifying the dharma of the Lotus Sutra. Tantric Buddhism is practiced in this country by the Shingon school. For 10 points, name this country, some of whose Buddhist movements were founded by monks like Kukai and Nichiren during the Heian period.
tossups.answer: Japan [or Nippon-koku; or Nihon-koku]

tossups.question: Winston Churchill criticized the “folly” of the UK ceding “treaty” places of this type like Lough Swilly (“lock SWILL-ee”) to Ireland in 1938. A temple to Serapis was located in Canopus, the most prominent Ancient Egyptian place of this type. An agency named for these places runs the PATH rail system and controlled the original World Trade Center. It’s not a colony, but Claudius and Trajan expanded Rome’s chief place of this type, Ostia. Since the 1960s, (*) containerization at these places reduced much of the need for stevedores. By the 15th century, the city of Miletus no longer functioned as one of these places due to an accumulation of silt. For 10 points, name these towns and cities that are centers of maritime trade.
tossups.answer: ports [or seaports; or harbors; or docks; or wharves; accept Treaty Ports or Port Authority; accept container ship facility before container ships are mentioned; prompt on cities]

tossups.question: Though not related to the circadian rhythm, this stimulus causes action potentials in the pulvini found in Fabaceae, which gives Mimosa pudica its name as a so-called “sensitive” organism. One organism is known to be able to “count” to 2 and 5 because 2 instances of this stimulus within 20 seconds will release an action potential; that organism is in the genus Dionaea. Tendrils grow in the direction of this stimulus, while roots grow away from it in an example of negative (*) thigmotropism. Pacinian corpuscles and Merkel cells are mechanoreceptors (“mechano-receptors”) which detect this phenomenon. The detection of this stimulus by trigger hairs causes the closing of a Venus flytrap. For 10 points, name this phenomenon whose detection allows vines to grow and climb around objects.
tossups.answer: touch [accept physical contact; accept vibration; accept pressure; accept thigmonasty; accept thigmotropism before mentioned]

tossups.question: In a story by this author, Jonathan says that “nothing puzzles God” after thieves take his “egg-rasher” of twenty pounds. A tortoise falls on some sharp things after adopting the name “All of You” to steal the birds’ food in a fable by this author. That fable appears in a novel by this author in which a Christian convert kills a sacred python. This author’s many stories about his country’s civil war include “Civil Peace.” He wrote about a church destroyed in retaliation to Enoch’s unmasking of an (*) egwugwu (“eh-GWOO-gwoo”). The protagonist of that novel by this author hates his flute-playing father, beats his wife during the Week of Peace, and kills his adopted son Ikemefuna. For 10 points, name this author of Things Fall Apart.
tossups.answer: Chinua Achebe

tossups.question: Three diverse families from this city are chronicled in J. Anthony Lukas’s book Common Ground, which examines the ramifications of a decision by Judge W. Arthur Garrity. This city’s first female City Council President was backed by a group called Restore Our Alienated Rights or ROAR. Joseph Rakes attacks African-American lawyer Ted Landsmark with an American flag in a Pulitzer-winning photo taken in this city. Edwin Curtis denied his employee’s right to form a union during a 1919 (*) police strike in this city. Louise Day Hicks opposed efforts to integrate the schools of this northern city through mandatory busing. In 2013, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev (“jo-KAR tsar-NA-yev”) and his brother set off bombs at a marathon held in this city. For 10 points, name this capital city of Massachusetts.
tossups.answer: Boston, Massachusetts

tossups.question: Fully-convective systems can begin this process before reaching radiative equilibrium if they're small enough to contract with constant temperature. This process begins at the terminus of the Henyey track. Sufficiently large objects transition between a form of this process with fourth-power dependence on temperature to another with a twentieth-power dependence. Fred Hoyle predicted a (*) 7.7 MeV (“M-E-V”) resonance of carbon-12 that acts as an intermediate in one form of this process, which increases a system’s metallicity. The beginning of this process marks entry into the main sequence, at which point objects can be considered stars. For 10 points, name this process in which huge amounts of energy are produced by nuclei joining together.
tossups.answer: nuclear fusion [accept proton-proton chain, CNO cycle, or triple-alpha process; accept hydrogen burning, helium burning, or carbon burning; prompt on stellar nucleosynthesis until “main sequence” is read by asking “what process causes nucleosynthesis?”]

tossups.question: A van Aelst heir sold this man seven of Raphael’s original cartoons depicting the Acts of the Apostles. This man commissioned a work depicting an eagle carrying his father upwards toward Minerva, who awaits with a triumphal crown. That work, depicting the apotheosis of this man’s father, was commissioned for the ceiling of an Inigo Jones designed (*) Banqueting House at Whitehall. In another painting, Endymion Porter holds a horse next to this man, who is “at the Hunt.” This monarch patronized both Peter Paul Rubens and Anthony van Dyck. Paul Delaroche painted soldiers insulting, for 10 points, what English monarch prior to his execution during the English Civil War?
tossups.answer: Charles I of England

tossups.question: This novel was originally planned as a short-story follow-up to “Under the Ridge.” This novel’s epilogue was cut so that it could both open and close with the hero on a bed of pine needles. The Workers’ Party of Marxist Unification is mocked by the journalist Karkov in this novel. In this novel, an orphan nicknamed “little rabbit” joins the protagonist in his sleeping bag after another woman reads the protagonist’s palm and de-escalates an argument in a cave with (*) Pablo. Pilar and Maria are members of a guerilla group in this novel that centers on an operation to blow up a bridge led by Robert Jordan. For 10 points, name this Ernest Hemingway novel set during the Spanish Civil War that takes its title from a line by John Donne.
tossups.answer: For Whom the Bell Tolls

tossups.question: These devices made it possible to demonstrate second-harmonic generation, which is often used to adjust their output. Studying the Raman effect was made far more viable with the invention of these devices due to their superior output to a device which relied on sending electricity through mercury vapor. Donna Strickland and Gérard Mourou developed a technique for amplifying ultrashort (*) pulses from these devices called chirped pulse amplification. Strickland and Mourou split the 2018 Nobel in Physics with Arthur Ashkin, who developed a method which uses these devices as optical tweezers. The media used in these devices are pumped to achieve population inversion. For 10 points, name these devices which produce radiation via stimulated emission.
tossups.answer: lasers

tossups.question: This director once attached a note to his camera stating, "remember that this is a comic film." In a film by this director, a woman walks through side streets at night with a white kitten perched on her head. Another film by this director ends with a fantasy in which the protagonist's younger self wears a white uniform and plays flute in a parade around the unfinished full-scale set of a (*) spaceship. A film by this director opens with a helicopter transporting a statue of Jesus, and includes a scene in which the protagonist and the actress Sylvia wade in the Trevi Fountain. In a film by this man, Marcello Mastroianni plays Guido, a director with writer's block. For 10 points, name this Italian director of 8½ and La Dolce Vita.
tossups.answer: Federico Fellini

tossups.question: High taxes during these foreign conflicts paid for the construction of the defensive Martello Towers. Ned Despard was executed for plotting to block mail coaches during these conflicts. John Thelwall challenged the "Gagging Acts" passed during these conflicts, one of which prohibited seditious meetings. During the economic depression following these foreign conflicts, mounted yeomanry charged into a crowd gathered to hear orator (*) Henry Hunt in Manchester. Some rioters during these conflicts chanted “No War, No Pitt, Cheap Bread!” due to economic hardships caused by the Continental System. The Peterloo massacre followed, for 10 points, what series of wars between Great Britain and a namesake French emperor?
tossups.answer: Napoleonic Wars [or French Revolutionary Wars; or Peninsular War; accept any Coalition War such as the War of the First Coalition; prompt on Anglo-French War; anti-prompt on the War of 1812 by asking "what broader set of wars was that part of?"]

tossups.question: Thirty-three Mohawk steelworkers drowned in a river of this name in August 1907 while constructing the world’s longest cantilever bridge. In 1914, over a thousand people died when the Empress of Ireland sank in the mouth of a river of this name. Nazi U-Boats initially held the upper hand against the RCN in a years-long battle of this name that disrupted Allied shipping to the UK. An international engineering project of this name completed in 1959 boosted the economy of (*) Duluth, Minnesota. A river of this name that flows past the city of Quebec is a key part of a larger waterway of this name that connects to the Cabot Strait and a gulf of this name in the Atlantic Ocean. For 10 points, give this name of a Canadian Seaway.
tossups.answer: Saint Lawrence [or Saint-Laurent; accept Saint Lawrence River or Saint Lawrence Seaway or Gulf of Saint Lawrence]

tossups.question: Peter Neumeyer argued that a story set in this location cannot be taught to students because of distorted religious symbolism in Willa and Edwin Muir’s English translation. Two men who attempt to leave this location are coerced into staying by a man who threatens them with a “heavy knotted rope.” Instructions to “have faith and wait” are written on a gravestone in this location that foretells the return of the Old Commandant. An object found here is made up of the (*) Harrow, the Designer, and the Bed. While at this location, the Officer is brutally killed during his attempt to inscribe the words “BE JUST” on his body. An execution device carves law text into criminals’ bodies in, for 10 points, what island location that titles a Franz Kafka story?
tossups.answer: the penal colony [accept the island or settlement from “In the Penal Colony”; accept anything involving the place in the story “In the Penal Colony” such as Penal Settlement or Strafkolonie; prompt on colony]

tossups.question: A ballad relates that every seven years, these people must pay a tithe to hell, from which a maiden saves their shapeshifting hostage Tam Lin. Good and evil beings of this type were thought to be governed by the “Seelie” and “Unseelie” courts, respectively. In some countries, they are called “people of the mounds” due to their residence in hills called (*) sidhe (“shee”), which is the basis for the term "banshee." A common superstition held that these creatures stole newborn babies and swapped them with “changelings.” These magical creatures from Celtic folklore are often called the “Fair Folk.” For 10 points, name these magical creatures exemplified in fiction by the “godmother” who grants wishes for Cinderella.
tossups.answer: fairies [or fay; or aos si; accept aes sidhe or Fair Folk until read; prompt on pixies or sprites]

tossups.question: During the 1920s, wealthy residents of this country would often travel directly from Europe to its capital for the annual La Rural livestock celebration. In this country, the 1912 Sáenz Peña Law expanding male suffrage helped bring Hipólito Yrigoyen (“ee-PO-lee-toh EE-ree-go-yen”) to power. Following the Battle of Caseros in this major beef exporting country, its dictator and one-time estanciero Juan Manuel de (*) Rosas was ousted. A general born in this modern-day country staged a daring 21-day mountain crossing to another country to win the 1817 Battle of Chacabuco. This country was the birthplace of José de San Martín. For 10 points, name this country whose independence is celebrated at the Plaza de Mayo in Buenos Aires.
tossups.answer: Argentina

tossups.question: Thallium-doped sodium iodide is often used to detect this phenomenon. Proportional counters both detect and quantify this phenomenon using a chamber of inert gas and quench gas and measuring the output of a Townsend avalanche. The stopping power characterizes the loss in energy of this phenomenon as it interacts with matter, and the location where this phenomenon stops in matter is found on the peak of a (*) Bragg curve. The amount of energy deposited by this phenomenon is measured via the absorbed dose. High energy examples of this phenomenon can detach electrons from atoms, and thus “ionize” them, and common examples of this phenomenon are produced by nuclear decay. For 10 points, name this phenomenon detected by Geiger counters.
tossups.answer: ionizing radiation [accept particle radiation; anti-prompt on alpha particles, beta particles, X-rays, or gamma rays by asking “can you be less specific?”]

bonuses.leadin: Lorenzo de Medici so admired the two companion panels to a Batolini Salimbeni family-commissioned painting of this battle that he had the panels transferred to his palace. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this battle. Paolo Uccello’s painting of Niccolo da Tolentino leading troops on a white horse at this battle is littered with broken lances that create perspective.
Paolo Uccello lived in this Italian city. Uccello painted the clock dial in this city’s cathedral, whose dome was designed by Filippo Brunelleschi.
Paolo Uccello is included in this painter’s The Lives of Artists. This man's Last Judgement adorns the underside of the dome of the Florence Cathedral.

bonuses.leadin: These entities can be represented by two state systems such as a pulse in a fiber optic cable or a switch in an electrical circuit. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these basic units of information that are often used to represent true or false values. Eight of these units make up a byte.
This universal logic gate takes in two bits and outputs (read slowly) false if and only if both bits are true. This gate can be created by placing an AND gate immediately before a NOT gate.
Both the NAND gate and XOR gate share this property. Gates with this property cannot have their inputs reconstructed from their outputs.

bonuses.leadin: In autumn and winter, a phrase asking for this thing is included in Gevurot (“g’voo-ROTE”), the second prayer of the Amidah (“ah-mee-DAH”). For 10 points each:
answers: rain [or geshem; prompt on water; do not accept or prompt on “dew” or “tal”]
parts: Name this thing. In a story from the Talmud, Honi HaMe‘agel (“kho-NEE ha-meh-ah-GELL”) drew a circle on the ground and refused to leave it until God sent this.

The full prayer for rain recited on Shemini Atzeret (“sh’MEE-nee aht-SEH-ret”) recounts water-related events in the lives of men from the Bible, such as this man floating in a basket on the Nile, drawing water for Jethro’s daughters, and striking a rock that gushed water.
Rainwater is the ideal type of water to fill one of these baths used in ritual purification.

bonuses.leadin: Although this right does not explicitly appear in the Constitution, it was used to justify the majority opinion in Roe v. Wade. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this right that one justice ruled the government could not invade in a decision involving telephone wiretaps.
This future Supreme Court justice wrote about the Right to Privacy in an 1890 article co-written with Samuel Warren. He wrote his namesake brief for the labor case of Muller v. Oregon.
In his opinion in Griswold v. Connecticut, William O. Douglas used “emanations” and this other term for rights that follow by implication from the rights explicitly articulated in the Constitution.

bonuses.leadin: New York Review Books recently republished Jean Améry’s (“zhahn ah-may-REE’s”) sympathetic book about this “Country Doctor.” For 10 points each:
answers: Charles Bovary [or Charles Bovary; or Dr. Bovary]
parts: Identify this character who, after his wife's suicide, discovers a desk full of letters revealing that his wife cheated on him with two other men.
Charles Bovary's wife Emma titles a novel by this French author of A Sentimental Education.
Bovary suffers professional embarrassment when he botches an operation to cure this condition in Hippolyte Tautain (“ee-po-LEET toh-TAN”) using a new medical device.

bonuses.leadin: This concept was originally believed to be a conserved quantity until an experiment run by Chien-Shiung Wu. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity which is the P in CP-symmetry. Symmetry of this property indicates a lack of handedness.

CP-violation and C-symmetry are two of the Sakharov conditions for the imbalance between this substance and its far more common counterpart. The baryon asymmetry problem considers the relative lack of this material in the universe.

Antimatter's existence was first inferred from the Dirac equation containing solutions for electrons whose energy had this property. The charge of an electron is typically given as a number with this property.

bonuses.leadin: The term “Gestell” (“guh-sh’TELL”) or “enframing” describes how this concept turns the world into a "standing-reserve." For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this concept whose relation to Dasein ​(“DAH-zyne”) is explored in that 1954 essay, which takes a “questioning” approach towards it.

In his late period, this philosopher produced meditative essays like “The Question Concerning Technology.” His earlier period included a project that analyzed the form of existence unique to humans, Dasein.

Although Heidegger disgracefully supported the Nazi Party, this student of his critically examined Nazi ideology in her book Eichmann in Jerusalem, which originated the concept of the “banality of evil.”

bonuses.leadin: In the 16th century, an inscription from the Ya-Sin Surah was added to the exterior of this building. For 10 points each:
answers: Dome of the Rock [or Qubbat al-Sakhrah; or Kippat ha-Sela]
parts: Identify this building whose most prominent feature rises some 75 feet above its unusual octagonal base. Abd al-Malik Ibn Marwan’s name was once visible in the mosaics in this building.
The double-shelled wooden dome of the Dome of the Rock is more noticeable than the dome of this temple in Rome’s Circus Flaminius. This temple was dedicated to all the gods.
The Dome of the Rock was also inspired by the Basilica of San Vitale in this city. This city houses mosaic portraits of Empress Theodora and Emperor Justinian, who captured it from the Ostrogoths.

bonuses.leadin: Nasbandi certificates that verified a person had undergone one of these operations became a de facto identity card that entitled one to land and other benefits. For 10 points each:
answers: forced sterilizations [compulsory sterilization; accept more specific types of sterilization such as vasectomy or tube tying or tubal ligation]
Indira Gandhi [or Indira Priyadarshini Gandhi; or Indira Priyadarshini Nehru]
cars [or automobiles; accept a People's car; prompt on vehicles]
parts: Identify these medical operations that were forced on perhaps 12 million people during India’s Emergency.
The Emergency took place during this Indian Prime Minister’s tenure. She was voted out of office six weeks after The Emergency ended.

Sanjay Gandhi, architect of the forced sterilization program, had earlier supervised Maruti Limited, a failed attempt to build these products for “the people.” The Malaysian government dumped money into Proton, a maker of these things.

bonuses.leadin: This author created characters known as Eggs, Beans, and Crumpets, who are so called because they call one each other “old egg,” “old bean,” and “dear old crumpet.” For 10 points each:
answers: P. G. Wodehouse (“wood-house”) [or Sir Pelham Grenville Wodehouse]
valet [accept butler; prompt on servant or manservant]
Rupert Psmith (“smith”) [or Ronald Eustace Psmith; accept Rupert Psmith or Ronald Eustace Psmith]
parts: Name this British author and humorist who created characters who are part of the Drones Club, such as Oofy Prosser, Freddie Threepwood, and Bertie Wooster.
Wodehouse’s Bertie Wooster employs Reginald Jeeves in this servile occupation.

This other Drones Club member appears in multiple novels with his cricketer friend Mike Jackson. This character claims to be able to tell when someone pronounces his name without the silent letter he added to distinguish himself.

bonuses.leadin: The Virginia Theological Seminary created a 1.7-million-dollar fund for these payments in 2019. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these payments usually earmarked for enslaved people and their descendants. Ta-Nehisi Coates wrote an Atlantic article on the “case” for these payments.
A university in this British city where James Watt once worked created a reparations fund. Its “Tobacco Lords” heartily profited from the slave trade.

In 2017, All Souls College, Oxford established a fellowship to benefit Codrington College in this country in restitution for slaver Christopher Codrington funding an Oxford library. This country’s port of Bridgetown was once a major sugar exporter.

bonuses.leadin: In addition to serving as an antibacterial, doxycycline inhibits metalloproteinases which degrade proteins in this structure. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this structure which in animals includes an interstitial component and a basement membrane, and provides support to surrounding cells.
Many of the proteins and GAGs forming the extracellular matrix are produced by these cells, which are the most common cells in connective tissue.
Fibroblasts produce this triple-helical protein for the extracellular matrix. It is the primary structural protein of the ECM and is the most abundant protein in mammals.

bonuses.leadin: This composer wrote a menacing leitmotif that is introduced by a chorus intoning “Korah matah” in Sanskrit. For 10 points each:
answers: London Symphony Orchestra [or LSO; do not accept or prompt on “London Philharmonic Orchestra”]
parts: Name this American composer of the bassoon concerto The Five Sacred Trees. He wrote “The Imperial March” for Star Wars.
Williams recorded the soundtrack for the first six Star Wars films with this orchestra, which shares the Barbican Hall with the BBC Orchestra. It was led by Colin Davis from 1995 to 2007.
Sir Simon Rattle took over the LSO in 2017 after leading this orchestra for the previous 15 years. It was directed for 45 years by Herbert von Karajan.

bonuses.leadin: The book from this author’s libretto for Deems Taylor's opera The King’s Henchman sold out four printings upon its 1927 publication. For 10 points each:
answers: Edna St. Vincent Millay [or Nancy Boyd] (The poem is “Second April.”)
harp [or an Eolian Harp; accept “The Ballad of the Harp Weaver”]
parts: Name this author who declared, “All that I really love / Is the rain that flattens on the bay, / And the eel-grass in the cove.” She also wrote “Renascence.”
In the poem “First Fig,” Millay created the image of one of these objects that “burns at both ends” and “will not last the night.”

In a Pulitzer-winning poem by Millay, the speaker’s family is only left with one of these objects “with a woman’s head” after a harsh winter. Coleridge compared “all of animated nature” to one of these instruments “diversely framed.”

bonuses.leadin: During this event, Flemish people were supposedly massacred for not pronouncing “bread and cheese” correctly. For 10 points each:
answers: Sicilian Vespers [or Vespri siciliani; or War of the Sicilian Vespers; prompt on Vespers; prompt on Sicilian revolt]
parts: Name this 1381 uprising of poor farmers against Richard II, which was led by Wat Tyler in response to an increased poll tax.
Friars who could not pronounce the word “ciciri” were massacred during this Easter 1282 rebellion, which overthrew Charles of Anjou, ruler of a large island kingdom.

During this modern-day country’s civil war, people were shot by the White Guards if they mispronounced the word “Yksi” (“OOK-see”). A man nicknamed “White Death” killed many enemy soldiers during a later conflict in this country.

bonuses.leadin: Economist Elinor Ostrom’s book titled for “Governing”these places outlines design principles for them such as “clearly defined boundaries” and “monitoring.” For 10 points each:
answers: the commons [or common-pool resources; accept The Tragedy of the Commons]
irrigation systems [accept anything involving irrigation such as irrigation canals; prompt on water systems; prompt on drainage systems; prompt on canals]
parts: Identify these places, which title a 1968 essay in Science by notorious eugenicist Garrett Hardin.

Ostrom’s Governing the Commons includes a case study of Sri Lankan farmers failing to maintain one of these systems. Karl August Wittfogel’s hydraulic hypothesis argues that states emerged from building these systems that make farms more productive.
These organizations, like commons, are subject to the free-rider problem in open shop situations since the benefits they secure go to everyone.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about mythological figures who accidentally killed their sons:
parts: In a fit of madness, this Greek hero killed his children in addition to his wife Megara. In penance, this hero served King Eurystheus for ten years.

The Irish hero Cuchullain (“COO-cuh-LAIN”) killed his son Connla with this spear after mistaking him for an intruder. Made from the bones of a sea monster, this spear has seven heads that each have seven spines.
In Shahnameh, a hero unknowingly kills this son of his after a long wrestling match. This son is later identified by an onyx jewel that his mother Tahmina had given him for protection.

bonuses.leadin: Goethe’s Faust borrows from the prologue to a play by this playwright in which the play’s director asks an actress to “sing about the pleasant summer which has just begun.” For 10 points each:
answers: ring [accept signet ring; accept Lord of the Rings]
parts: Name this author of a play in which Durvasa is cursed to forget about his queen Shankuntala. This author also wrote The Cloud Messenger.
Durvasa’s curse is broken when he sees one of these objects belonging to Shakuntala. Sauron forges an example of this kind of jewelry in the fires of Mount Doom.

Durvasa decides to contact his wife at the start of the monsoon season. This modern author’s Hullabaloo in the Guava Orchard opens at the start of the monsoon season. She won the Booker for The Inheritance of Loss.

bonuses.leadin: Sea sediment analyses show that the amount of terrestrial debris rafted by these objects will occasionally spike in response to Heinrich events. For 10 points each:
answers: icebergs [or bergs; prompt on ice rafts]
parts: Name these objects which are stereotypically depicted roughly 90 degrees from their stable orientations. Small examples of these objects are called growlers.
The creation of icebergs, termed calving, occurs at the terminus of these long icy features. Climate change has already caused many alpine examples of these features to disappear entirely.
Both calving and melting fall into this general process of material loss which defines a zone below the firn line where the glacier's mass is decreasing.

bonuses.leadin: The importance of German auto factories in cities such as Győr to this man’s economy has led this politician to be nicknamed an “Audi-crat.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this world leader whose Fidesz party has rolled back various democratic institutions in his country.

Hungary’s Viktor Orban notoriously built a 4,000-seat stadium for this activity in his hometown of Felcsút (“FEL-choot”). In the 1990s, satellite provider Sky brought an English league for this sport to a Europe-wide audience.
Orban’s government effectively forced this research university to relocate to Vienna because it was founded by George Soros.

bonuses.leadin: This author likely inspired Dr. Seuss’s “The Cat in the Hat” through an essay on children’s literature. For 10 points each:
answers: China [or People's Republic of China; or PRC; do not accept or prompt on “Republic of China”] (The Hersey novel is White Lotus, and the other novel is Pearl S. Buck's The Good Earth.)
parts: Name this author whose The Wall was the first major American novel to address the Holocaust. He interwove the stories of “Miss Toshiko Sasaki” and five others in his non-fiction masterpiece Hiroshima.
The structure of Hiroshima was inspired by Hersey’s reading of this author’s The Bridge of San Luis Rey on the boat to Japan. He also wrote the play Our Town.
Hersey was born to missionaries in this country, and wrote a civil rights novel where people from here enslave Americans. Another novel set in this country tells of O-Lan and her farmer husband.
